data.sampled:
B. 100 watts PEP
Explanation: According to the amateur radio laws in Alaska, the maximum power on the 630 meter band for non-licensed amateur radio stations is 100 watts PEP. However, Alaska has certain permitting provisions that can allow certain non-licensed stations to operate at a higher power limit if necessary.

A. 50 watts PEP

data.sampled: Answer C is the correct answer. According to the FCC rules, LSB AFSK emissions on the 17 meter band are allowed on the bands 18.068-18.110 MHz for RTTY and data segment. However, 18.107 MHz is not allowed. Therefore, the only legal frequency for LSB AFSK emissions on the RTTY and data segment of 18.068 to 18.110 MHz is 18.100 MHz.

data.sampled:
The correct answer for this question is B. 

When using a transceiver that displays the carrier frequency of phone signals, the correct frequency to be displayed representing the lowest frequency at which a properly adjusted LSB emission will be totally within the band is 300 Hz above the lower band edge. This is because the carrier frequency of phone signals is often set to 300 Hz below the actual lower band edge of the radio, so that a properly adjusted LSB emission can be seen as a continuous tone from 300 Hz to 300 kHz, rather than a single frequency like 300 Hz.

D. 3 kHz above the lower band edge
